title: Academic self-concept in science: Multidimensionality, relations to achievement measures, and gender differences ☆
abstract: Students' academic self-concept is a good predictor of academic achievement and a desirable educational outcome per se. In this study, we take a closer look at the nature of the academic self-concept in the natural sciences by examining its dimensional structure, its relation to achievement, and gender differences. We analyzed data from self-concept measures, grades and standardized achievement tests of 6036 German 10th graders across three science subjectsbiology, chemistry, and physicsusing structural equation modeling. Results indicate that (a) a 3-dimensional, subject-specific measurement model of the self-concept in science is preferable to a 1-dimensional model, (b) the relations between the self-concept and achievement are substantial and subjectspecific when grades are used as achievement indicators, and (c) female students possess a lower self-concept in chemistry and physics even after controlling for achievement measures. Therefore, we recommend conceptualizing the self-concept in science as a multidimensional, subject-specific construct both in educational research and in science classes.

abstract.text: Students' academic self-concept is a good predictor of academic achievement and a desirable educational outcome per se. In this study, we take a closer look at the nature of the academic self-concept in the natural sciences by examining its dimensional structure, its relation to achievement, and gender differences. We analyzed data from self-concept measures, grades and standardized achievement tests of 6036 German 10th graders across three science subjectsbiology, chemistry, and physicsusing structural equation modeling. Results indicate that (a) a 3-dimensional, subject-specific measurement model of the self-concept in science is preferable to a 1-dimensional model, (b) the relations between the self-concept and achievement are substantial and subjectspecific when grades are used as achievement indicators, and (c) female students possess a lower self-concept in chemistry and physics even after controlling for achievement measures. Therefore, we recommend conceptualizing the self-concept in science as a multidimensional, subject-specific construct both in educational research and in science classes.

body_text.text: Science, technology, engineering, and mathematics (STEM) education is regarded as crucial by policy makers as shown in official statements; for example, "leadership tomorrow depends on how we educate our students today, especially in math, science, technology, and engineering" (The White House, 2010, para. 6). Such spirited statements have been backed up by scientific research that shows that achievement in STEMmeasured indirectly by the number of patents and Nobel Prize laureates per capitais a good predictor of wealth on a national level (Rindermann & Thompson, 2011) . Therefore, various programs intend to strengthen education in STEM, some focusing on engaging more women to bridge "a gender gap to innovation" (United States Department of Commerce, 2011, p. 1). As mathematics and science cover the largest part of school education in STEM subjects, predicting academic success in these domains has become a goal for educational research.

The academic self-conceptthe self-perception of one's ability in an academic domainshows substantial positive relations to academic effort (Trautwein, Lüdtke, Schnyder, & Niggli, 2006) , the choice of academic courses (Marsh & Yeung, 1997) , and academic achievement (Marsh & Martin, 2011) . Meta-analyses (Huang, 2011; Valentine, DuBois, & Cooper, 2004) and longitudinal studies (Marsh & O' Mara, 2008) have shown that the relation between academic achievement and the self-concept is positive and reciprocal. The finding that students who feel more competent in a specific school subject will also achieve better results than their equally able peers makes the academic self-concept one of the most influential non-ability predictors of school achievement and, in general, a desirable educational outcome (OECD, 2003) . Whereas there are many studies on the academic self-concept in math and languages, few studies have focused on the self-concept in the domain of science even though it may be an important factor in explaining both students' academic success and their aspirations to pursue a career in the sciences. In this study, we scrutinize the nature of the academic selfconcept in science by examining its internal structure and its relation to student achievement. Furthermore, we investigate gender differences in the academic self-concept in science and the moderating effects of gender on the relation between the self-concept and student achievement.

Different conceptualizations of the internal structure of the academic self-concept have been proposed. One of the first models that introduced the assumption of the academic self-concept as a multidimensional construct, later called the Shavelson model (Shavelson, Hubner, & Stanton, 1976) , organizes different self-concepts hierarchically. It includes several higher order factors covering different facets of self-concept such as an emotional, a social, and an academic self-concept. Below the general academic self-concept factors are subject-specific self-concept factors. However, empirical results have shown that the self-concept in mathematics and the self-concept with regard to the language of instruction are almost uncorrelated, even though student abilities in the mathematical and verbal domains are strongly correlated (Marsh, 1986; Marsh, Byrne, & Shavelson, 1988 )-a pattern that is contrary to the idea of a general academic self-concept factor affecting all domain-specific selfconcepts. This pattern can be explained by the Internal/External frame of reference model (further referred to as the I/E model, Marsh, 1986) . It postulates that students use two comparison processes that rely on two different frames of reference to evaluate their ability in a given domain. On the one hand, they compare their achievement to the achievement of their peers (usually class mates) within the same domain-a social comparison within an external frame of reference resulting in positive effects of achievement on the self-concept within each domain. On the other hand, they compare their achievement in one domain with their own achievement in other domains-a dimensional comparison within an internal frame of reference resulting in negative effects of achievement in the verbal domain on the self-concept in the mathematical domain and vice versa (Möller & Marsh, 2013) . These negative across-domain effects of achievement on self-concept explain the almost nonexistent relation between mathematical and verbal self-concepts. To account for these processes and the implied distinction of the mathematical and the verbal domains, Marsh and colleagues also developed a new model of the internal structure of the academic self-concept, the Marsh/ Shavelson model (Marsh, 1990; Marsh & Shavelson, 1985; Marsh et al., 1988) . The Marsh/Shavelson model discards the idea of a general factor of academic self-concept in favor of two uncorrelated factors-a general mathematical and general verbal self-concept. Even though extensions have been proposed lately (Arens, Yeung, Craven, & Hasselhorn, 2011; Brunner, Lüdtke, & Trautwein, 2008; Brunner et al., 2010; Chiu, 2012) , the I/E model and the Marsh/Shavelson model have been supported by a vast amount of empirical data including cross-cultural studies (Marsh & Hau, 2004) , meta-analytic studies (Möller, Pohlmann, Köller, & Marsh, 2009) and longitudinal studies (Marsh & Köller, 2004; Marsh, Kong, & Hau, 2001; Möller, Retelsdorf, Köller, & Marsh, 2011) , and have guided much of the research on the academic self-concept.
body_text.section: The internal structure of academic self-concept

body_text.text: In the above-mentioned theoretical models, the academic selfconcept is considered subject-specific. Which science subjects are taught in a given learning environment varies, however: in contrast to some other countries in which the natural sciences are taught interdisciplinarily, science education in Germany is traditionally taught in three separate subjects in secondary school (physics, chemistry, and biology) even though interdisciplinary science classes are sometimes taught in lower grades or offered in addition to subject-specific teaching. Accordingly, different conceptualizations of the self-concept in science have been proposed: In the original Shavelson model, the self-concept in science was represented by a single first-order factor (Shavelson et al., 1976) . This conceptualization also underlies a prominent and widely used measure of academic self-concept-the Academic Self-Description Questionnaire (ASDQ; Marsh, 1990) . However, in the Marsh/Shavelson model (Marsh, 1990) , the physical and biological sciences are theoretically distinguished and strong assumptions concerning their relations to higher order factors are made; in detail, the physical science factor is explained solely by a higher order mathematics-and-science factor, whereas the biological science factor is explained by both a higher order verbal factor and the higher order mathematics-and-science-factor. In their description of the Marsh/Shavelson model, Möller and Köller (2004) differentiated between three science subjects: biology, physics, and chemistry, in accordance with the curriculum in Germany. In their model, the self-concepts in physics and chemistry are explained by a higher order mathematics factor, whereas the self-concept in biology is explained by a higher order verbal factor.
body_text.section: The structure of the academic self-concept in science

body_text.text: Reviewing the literature on the self-concept, curiously, self-concepts in the natural sciences play a minor role. Whether one or more science self-concept factors are assumed depends largely on the country in which the study was conducted and the curriculum. The allocation of the science self-concepts to the higher order factors of the Marsh/ Shavelson model seems to have been founded on the implicit assumption that the self-concepts in different science subjects can be ordered along a continuum ranging from a verbal to a mathematical pole. In this assignment, the self-concept in biology is located near the verbal pole and the self-concept in physics is located near the mathematical pole, whereas chemistry takes an intermediate role. Despite the plausibility of these assumptions at first glance (e.g., more mathematical formalization is used in school physics than in school biology), empirical data that capture the internal structure of self-concepts in science covering all three subjects are missing.
body_text.section: The structure of the academic self-concept in science

body_text.text: Most studies on the structure of the academic self-concept are not conducted in the domain of science. Similarly, the relation between academic self-concept and achievement is often reduced to mathematics and languages. In the few studies that consider science achievement, the self-concept in science is either regarded as a one-dimensional construct, or the analyses focus on one domain of science: Only weak relations between the science self-concept and science achievementas measured by standardized achievement testswere found in a student sample from Hong Kong (Wang, Oliver, & Starver, 2008) , whereas others found substantial positive relations (e.g., Chiu, 2008 Chiu, , 2012 . Other studies focused on specific science domains only and consistently found positive effects. For example, the self-concept in chemistry was found to be a valid predictor of course grades in chemistry (Bauer, 2005) , performance on an examination of the American Chemical Society (Lewis, Shaw, & Heitz, 2009) , and the understanding of chemical concepts (Nieswandt, 2007) . Substantial correlations have also been found between the self-concept in biology and a test on genetics (Thomas et al., 1993) , between the self-concept in life science and course grades (Britner, 2008) and between the self-concept and course grades in physics (Möller, Streblow, Pohlmann, & Köller, 2006) . Overall, these studies suggest a positive relation between the academic selfconcept and achievement, especially when the operationalization of achievement and self-concept is domain-specific and when grades are used as achievement indicators. However, a substantial drawback of these studies is that the extent to which the relation between the selfconcept and achievement is actually subject-specific remains unclear because different science subjects are not considered simultaneously.
body_text.section: The self-concept and achievement in science

body_text.text: The lack of studies that have considered multiple science subjects also constitutes a desideratum for further research considering the impact of dimensional comparisons on self-concept formation that is formulated in the I/E model (Marsh, 1986; Möller & Marsh, 2013) . Whereas numerous studies have shown contrast effect of dimensional comparisons (i.e., negative relations between achievement and selfconcept across subjects) when mathematics and the language of instruction are examined (Möller et al., 2009) , the evidence is mixed when more similar subjects (e.g., mathematics and science) are considered. In this case, both contrast and assimilation effects have been found. For example, Möller et al. (2006) tested the I/E model across two verbal (German, English) and two mathematical subjects (math, physics). Self-reported grades in both mathematical subjects were negatively related to the self-concepts in both verbal subjects, and grades in both verbal subjects were negatively related to the self-concepts in both mathematical subjects, thus, showing contrast effects between domains. However, within both domains, assimilation effects were found-that is, achievement in one subject (e.g., math) was positively related to the self-concept in the other subject from the same domain (e.g., physics). Chiu (2008 Chiu ( , 2012 tested the I/E model within the mathematical domain by examining the self-concept and test scores in math and science. Contrary to Möller's study, no assimilation effects across subjects were found. Achievement in one subject (e.g., math) and the self-concept in another subject (e.g., science) were negatively related -a pattern similar to the original I/E model. It should be mentioned, however, that the contrast effects were weaker than typically found between subjects from different domains, and, that the effects varied between the 28 countries examined resulting in small assimilation effects in some countries. Thus, the mechanism of relations between achievement and the self-concept across different science subjects is yet unclear and likely depends on the student-perceived similarity of subject characteristics (Möller & Marsh, 2013) .
body_text.section: The self-concept and achievement in science

body_text.text: The academic self-concept can predict academic choices (Marsh & Yeung, 1997; Wigfield & Eccles, 2000) in general and career aspirations in science in particular (Nagengast, Marsh, Scalas, Xu, Hau, & Trautwein, 2011) . Identifying potential gender differences in students' science selfconcept may therefore further our understanding of the gender gap in STEM subjects beyond many other factors that have been discussed such as general cognitive abilities (Kuhn & Holling, 2009) , specific mathematical ability (Brunner, Krauss, & Kunter, 2008) , profiles of interests (Su, Rounds, & Armstrong, 2009) , science anxiety (Brownlow, Jacobi, & Rogers, 2000; Mallow, 1994) or stereotype threat (Keller & Dauenheimer, 2003; Spencer, Steele, & Quinn, 1999) .
body_text.section: The self-concept in science and gender

body_text.text: It is important to note that this gender gap is not present in all STEM subjects. Hyde and Linn (2006) pointed out that "women earn 46% of the Ph.D.'s in biology but, despite evidence for gender similarities, they earn only 25% of the Ph.D.'s in physical science" (p. 600). Differences in interest profiles as condensed in the hypothesis "Men and Things, Women and People" (Su et al., 2009) can contribute to these subject-specific differences because human biology is an important part of the school curriculum and more concerned with "people" than the abstract science subjects of chemistry and physics. The subject-specific gender differences in self-concepts may explain why the gender gap occurs in physics, but not in biology.
body_text.section: The self-concept in science and gender

body_text.text: At least three kinds of potential gender differences may be of interest. First, the structure of the academic self-concept may vary across gender. This means that the factor loadings, intercepts and residual variances of the measurement model or the covariances between the latent factors may vary across gender groups (Little, 1997; Meredith, 1993) . Second, provided that the instruments show measurement invariance, female and male students may differ in the means of their science selfconcepts. Third, gender may also moderate the strength and pattern of relations between the academic self-concept and achievement data.
body_text.section: The self-concept in science and gender

body_text.text: The evidence concerning measurement invariance of the multidimensional and hierarchical structure of the self-concept across gender is mixed. In their examination of academic and non-academic selfconcept facets, Byrne and Shavelson (1987) found an equal number of factors and equal factor loadings across gender. However, the relations between the first-order self-concept factors differed: The self-concept of female students in the verbal domain showed a stronger relation to the general self-concept than the self-concept in the mathematical domain. For male students, this effect was reversed. Marsh (1993) found no gender differences in relations between general academic selfconcept, mathematical self-concept and verbal self-concept. However, both studies did not include specific measures of science self-concepts establishing a need for further research.
body_text.section: The self-concept in science and gender

body_text.text: With regard to mean differences, a stereotypical pattern of differences in several school subjects has been consistently found-whereas male students show a higher self-concept in math and science, female students show a higher self-concept in the verbal domain (e.g. Marsh, 1989; Marsh & Yeung, 1998; Wigfield, 1994) . With regard to specific science subjects, Schilling, Sparfeldt, and Rost (2006) found a higher selfconcept in biology and physics for male students even after controlling for achievement. This is consistent with results from the Trends in International Mathematics and Science Studies (TIMSS) that showed self-concept differences in physics in favor of male students (e.g., Köller & Klieme, 2000) . However with regards to the self-concept in biology the results are contrary to those found by Nagy and Colleagues (Nagy, Trautwein, Köller, Baumert, & Garrett, 2006) who reported a higher biology selfconcept for girls even though boys scored higher in the biology achievement tests used in the same study.
body_text.section: The self-concept in science and gender

body_text.text: To the best of our knowledge, moderating effects of gender on the relation between different self-concepts of science and achievement have not yet been reported in the literature. Knowledge of possible moderating effects is a prerequisite of meaningful cross-group comparisons (e.g. the comparisons of self-concepts while controlling for achievement), however, and would also be important for developing interventions to foster the self-concept in science subjects.
body_text.section: The self-concept in science and gender

body_text.text: Considering previous research on the academic self-concept in science, a lack of empirical data regarding the structure of the self-concept and its relation to achievement data is evident. Most studies either assume a one-dimensional self-concept in science or study only one specific science subject. The academic self-concepts in biology, chemistry, and physics have not been examined simultaneously so far. Only by doing so, however, is it possible to disentangle differential relations to other factors such as gender and achievement. In the present study, we analyze the subject-specific self-concepts and achievement measures (grades and test-scores) in three science subjects to address three research questions regarding the dimensionality of the self-concept in science.

The first research question addresses the factorial structure of academic self-concept in science. Can it be regarded as a one-dimensional construct, or are the differences in the science self-concepts stronger than their similarities? In order to provide answers to this question, competing measurement models were tested. More specifically, we compared a one-dimensional model (general self-concept in science) with a subject-specific three-dimensional model (self-concept factors in biology, chemistry, and physics). If a subject-specific model was found to be superior, we planned to examine the strength of relations between the three self-concept factors in more detail. We hypothesized that the relations between the self-concept factors in chemistry and physics which are assigned to the mathematical factor in the Marsh/Shavelson model (Möller & Köller, 2004) and contain more quantitative aspects such as mathematical formalization would be higher than the relations of each of these factors with the self-concept in biology. We also planned to test the measurement models of academic self-concept for invariance across school track. In Germany, students transfer to different school types after elementary school. Broadly speaking, the secondary school system differentiates between track schools preparing for university (Gymnasium) and vocationally oriented non-academic track schools (e.g., Sekundarschule). In the academic track schools, students have more science lessons and the science topics are covered in more depth which may potentially lead to differences in the self-concept structure.

The second research question concerns the relations between the academic self-concept and academic achievement in science. In general, the relation between academic self-concept and achievement has been described as positive, reciprocal, and subject-specific (Marsh & Martin, 2011; Valentine et al., 2004) . Specifically in the field of the natural sciences, this relation has rarely been tested systematically and with achievement data other than grades. If a three-factor model was found to be preferable to a one-dimensional model, we expected a specific self-concept factor to be more strongly related to its corresponding achievement factor than to the other two achievement factors. This pattern of differential relations was expected to be found using grades as well as test scores. Because grades are a salient source of individual feedback for students (e.g., Marsh, Trautwein, Lüdtke, Köller, & Baumert, 2005) and their best available information for social comparisons, we assumed that the connection would be stronger for grades. In contrast to previous studies, we examined all three subjects simultaneously, enabling us to analyze across-subject relations between the self-concept and achievement. Although the I/E model predicts negative contrast effects for clearly distinct domains such as maths and English, there is mixed evidence as to whether achievement and the self-concept in subjects that can be considered more similar (e.g., different science subjects) are positively (Möller et al., 2006) or negatively related (Chiu, 2008 (Chiu, , 2012 . We will, therefore, conduct path analyses to explore whether contrast or assimilation effects emerge between biology, chemistry and physics.

The third research question concerns the structure of the academic self-concept in science and its relation to academic achievement within gender groups. We planned to test the established measurement model (either one-or three-dimensional) for invariance across gender groups. If measurement invariancea necessary prerequisite for interpreting latent mean differenceswas to be established, we planned to examine potential gender differences in the means of self-concept factors and in the correlations between those latent factors. Consistent with previous results, we expected the self-concept in physics to be higher for male students even after controlling for differences in science achievement. Even though there are no previous results on gender differences in chemistry self-concept, we expected it to be higher for male students as chemistry is assigned to the mathematical factor of the Marsh/ Shavelson model (Möller & Köller, 2004) and stereotypical gender differences in the mathematical self-concept have consistently been found (Marsh, 1989; Marsh & Yeung, 1998; Wigfield, 1994) . Because there is mixed evidence on gender differences in self-concept means in biology (Nagy et al., 2006; Schilling et al., 2006) , we conducted exploratory analyses. To be able to meaningfully interpret self-concept differences while controlling for achievement we tested for moderating effects of gender, that is, diverging patterns of the relations between self-concepts and achievement data across gender.

This large-scale study was embedded in the process of establishing national performance scales in science in Germany. The study was conducted in eight German federal states. Within each federal state 20 schools were drawn with a mix of academic track schools (Gymnasium), intermediate track schools (Realschule) and mixed-track schools (e.g. Gesamtschule, Mittelschule) using probability-proportional-to-size sampling resulting in a sample of 158 participating schools. Within each school, two 10th-grade classes were drawn randomly. Because some schools had only one class, the sampling procedure resulted in 299 classes and a total of N = 7413 high school students. In our analyses, we used a subsample of n = 6036 students who, in addition to the achievement test, completed a self-concept questionnaire. The mean age was 15.49 years (SD = 0.68), and half of the sample was female (51.1%). About half of the students were from the academic track (48.3%), another third were from the intermediate track (34.0%), and 17.6% were from mixed-track school forms. The test session took a total of 3 h; 2 h for the achievement test and 1 h for the student questionnaire and additional measures. The data were collected in autumn 2009.

Due to the large number of items in both the achievement test and the student questionnaire, a multimatrix design was used (Gonzalez & Rutkowski, 2010) . Each student worked on about 40 science achievement items (M = 39.7, SD = 16.57) and completed a questionnaire assessing the self-concept in two of the three science subjects.

The self-concepts in biology, chemistry, and physics were assessed using three scales that were shown to be highly reliable in the Programme for International Student Assessment (PISA) 2006 study (OECD, 2009) and are frequently used in other self-concept research (e.g., Nagengast & Marsh, 2012; Nagengast et al., 2011). The 4-point scales included six items per subject. Whereas the original items in PISA assessed a uniform self-concept in science, we modified the items to match the three science subjects (i.e., biology, chemistry and physics) that are mandatory part of the curricula in secondary school in Germany and should, therefore, be salient for the students when evaluating their science ability. In other studies on academic self-concept similar, subject-specific items were used (Möller et al., 2006; Schilling et al., 2006) . Except for this modification, the same wording was used for all three subjectsfor example -"I learn [biology/chemistry/physics] topics quickly" or "I can easily understand new ideas in [biology/ chemistry/physics]." Both the internal consistencies and the composite reliabilities (ω; McDonald, 1999) were excellent (biology: α = .92, ω = .92; chemistry: α = .94, ω = .94; physics: α = .94, ω = .94).

Achievement in the three science subjects was measured using grades as well as standardized test scores. School officials reported the grades of the school year 2008/2009 in biology, chemistry, and physics as well as math and German for each student. The German grading system ranges from 1 (excellent) to 6 (insufficient). For easier interpretation, the grades were then reverse coded so that higher grades reflect higher achievement. If one of the subjects was not taught in the school year in question, a missing value was recorded for the corresponding students. The standardized tests were specifically designed to measure science achievement as defined by the national educational standards for science in Germany (for a detailed description of the theoretical model underlying item construction, see Neumann, Fischer, & Kauertz, 2010; Walpuski, 2010; Wellnitz, Hartmann, & Mayer, 2010) . In total, 350 different test items were used for biology, 354 for chemistry, and 417 for physics. More than half of the items were multiple-choice items (57.7%), 12.3% required the students to write short answers, and 29.9% required the students to write extended answers.

Due to the incomplete block design, about a third of the questionnaire data (biology: 32.7%, chemistry: 33.3%, physics: 34.0%) for each subject was missing (planned missingness; Enders, 2010). As students were administered the different versions of the questionnaire at random, these data may be considered missing completely at random (MCAR; Schafer & Graham, 2002) . In addition to the planned missingness, the rate of missing data for the 18 items measuring academic self-concept was low ranging from 0.5% to 1.5%. Further, 17.9% of the grades in biology, 10.6% of the grades in chemistry, and 19.9% of the grades in physics were missing because the specific subject was not part of the curricula at the time of testing. Test scores for 53.9% (biology), 68.6% (chemistry), and 55.9% (physics) of the students were missing by design, that is, no item of that particular scale was administered to the students. This missingness can also be considered MCAR.

Data analysis was carried out using Full Information Maximum Likelihood (FIML) estimation-a model-based approach to handling missing data implemented in Mplus 6.1 (Muthén & Muthén, 2011 ; see also Allison, 2001 ). In the FIML procedure, rather than deleting or imputing missing values beforehand, missing data and parameter estimation are combined in a single step and all available information is used (Enders, 2010) . FIML is superior to traditional methods of treating missing data (e.g., listwise or pairwise deletion or single imputation techniques) as it allows for more precise parameter estimation (unbiased under the Missing at Random (MAR) assumption; Enders & Bandalos, 2001 ) and higher statistical power (Schafer & Graham, 2002) .

The research questions were addressed within the frameworks of confirmatory factor analyses (CFA) and structural equation modeling (SEM) using a maximum likelihood estimator with robust standard errors (MLR). Models were compared using the Satorra-Bentler (S-B) scaled χ 2 -difference test (Satorra & Bentler, 1994) and additional fit indices. As the χ 2 statistic tends to be overly sensitive even for trivial model misfit when the sample size and the number of model parameters are large, we also examined on the Comparative Fit Index (CFI), the Root Mean Square Error of Approximation (RMSEA), and the Standardized Root Square Residual (SRMR) in case of a significant χ 2 test and used the guidelines by Hu and Bentler (1999) for evaluation of goodness of fit. They propose that a CFI above .95, a RMSEA below .06 and a SRMR below .08 indicate a well-fitting model.

In order to meaningfully interpret mean group differences (i.e., across gender), strong measurement invariancethat is, factor loadings and intercepts constrained to be equal across groupsis generally considered a necessary prerequisite (De Beuckelaer & Swinnen, 2011; Little, 1997; Meredith, 1993) . Some researchers recommend that strict measurement invariancethat is, factor loadings, intercepts and residuals constrained to be equal across groupsshould hold (DeShon, 2004; Lubke & Dolan, 2003; Wu, Li, & Zumbo, 2007) . Therefore, we assessed measurement invariance by testing hierarchically organized multigroup CFA (MGCFA) models, adding more equality constraints with every consecutive model. Because the χ 2 -difference test is very sensitive to sample size and tends to be significant even for small differences in model fit when many model parameters are manipulated at once as in invariance testing of factor loadings, intercepts and residual variances, we relied on the CFI because it is among the best performing fit indices for these invariance tests (Cheung & Rensvold, 2002) . The suggestions for CFI differences that indicate that the null hypothesis of model equality should not be rejected range from ΔCFI b .01 (Cheung & Rensvold, 2002) to ΔCFI b .002 (Meade, Johnson, & Braddy, 2008) . To test for invariance of structural parameters (i.e., factor covariances and regression coefficients) where fewer parameters are manipulated at once and, where the CFI and the RMSEA do not show enough sensitivity for small, but meaningful differences (e.g. in correlations; Hu & Bentler, 1998), we used the χ 2difference test.

To evaluate structural relations between the academic self-concept and achievement, multiple indicator multiple cause (MIMIC) models were specified. In order to control for teachers' class-related grading and because our substantive interest was located on the individual student level, grades were centered on the class mean (Enders & Tofighi, 2007) . To estimate science ability from the test items, we used weighted likelihood estimates (WLEs; Warm, 1989 ) of a one-parameter logistic IRT model for dichotomous items. The data were scaled separately for each science subject showing acceptable person separation reliabilities (Wu, Adams, Wilson, & Haldane, 2007) for the WLEs (biology: 0.71, chemistry: .79, physics = .74). We used ConQuest 2.0 for IRT scaling and computing WLEs. The grades and WLEs were then used as manifest covariates in MIMIC models estimated in Mplus 6.1 (Muthén & Muthén, 2011) . To account for the multilevel structure of the data, that is, students nested within classes, we corrected standard errors with the complex sampling option in Mplus (type = complex). To estimate the effect size of differences between gender groups, we used Cohen's d (Cohen, 1988) as adapted to multigroup latent mean comparisons by Hancock (2001) .

Descriptive statistics for all self-concept scales are listed in Table 1 . With values between − 0.41 and 0.23 for skewness and − 0.79 and − 0.09 for kurtosis, univariate normality could be assumed (see Kline, 2010) . As indicated by the intraclass correlations (ICCs), most of the self-concept variance was located on the individual rather than the class or school level. This is consistent with the assumption that students evaluate their ability within the reference frame of their class (Marsh, 1987) . The correlations between the three selfconcept scales, the achievement measures used in the further analyses as well as grades in German and math are shown in Table 2 . The correlations give a first indication that self-concept and achievement are positively correlated within each subject. As expected, the self-concept factors in physics and chemistry showed a stronger relation to math grade than to German grade; whereas the self- Note. SC = self-concept; B = biology; C = chemistry; P = physics; ICC c = intraclass correlation on class level; ICC s = intraclass correlation on school level. Information on gender is missing for one student. The items were phrased as follows, SC 1: "Learning advanced [biology/chemistry/physics] topics would be easy for me"; SC 2: "I can usually give good answers to test questions on [biology/chemistry/physics] topics"; SC 3: "I learn [biology/chemistry/physics] topics quickly"; SC 4: "[biology/chemistry/physics] topics are easy for me"; SC 5: "When I am being taught [biology/chemistry/physics], I can understand the concepts very well"; SC 6: "I can easily understand new ideas in [biology/chemistry/physics]." The response options were "strongly agree" (coded as 4), "agree" (3), "disagree" (2), and "strongly disagree" (1).
concept in biology showed correlations of comparable magnitude to the grades in math and in German.

To explore whether the academic self-concept in science is a general or a subject-specific construct, we first compared a one-dimensional model (one-factor model) with a subject-specific measurement model (three-factor model). Additionally, we tested whether the correlation between the self-concept factors in chemistry and physics was higher than the correlations of each of these factors with self-concept in biology. Therefore, a subject-specific model in which the correlation between the latent self-concept factors in chemistry and physics was freely estimated while the other two correlations were constrained to be equal was estimated. This model was then compared with the unconstrained model and a model in which all three correlations between the selfconcept factors were constrained to be equal.
body_text.section: The structure of the self-concept in science

body_text.text: As shown in Table 3 , the model fits of the one-dimensional and the subject-specific measurement models differed substantially. The three subject-specific models showed a good overall fit using the cutoff criteria proposed by Hu and Bentler (1999) , whereas the onedimensional model was not suitable for describing the empirical data.
body_text.section: The structure of the self-concept in science

body_text.text: The relations between the three self-concept factors were positive but considerably lower than the correlations between achievement measures in the three science subjects (see Table 2 ). The three-factor model in which the correlations between the self-concept factors chemistry and biology as well as physics and biology were constrained to be equal fits the data equally well as the unconstrained three-factor model (S-B Δχ 2 (N = 6036, df = 1) = 7.62, p = .006). The model in which all three correlations were constrained to be equal fits the data worse (S-B Δχ 2 (N = 6036, df = 1) = 38.83, p b .001) meaning that the relations between the three factors were not entirely uniform. As predicted, chemistry and physics were more strongly related (r = .49, also see Fig. 1 ) than were both of these subjects and biology.
body_text.section: The structure of the self-concept in science

body_text.text: Next, we tested the three-dimensional model for measurement invariance across school tracks and then constrained the factor covariances to be equal as well (see Table 4 ). Using the cut-off values for CFI differences by Cheung and Rensvold (ΔCFI b .01, 2002) , a strict measurement invariance could be established. While the more strict criterion suggested by Meade and colleagues (ΔCFI b .002; Meade et al., 2008) was narrowly missed for the strong invariance model and the strict invariance model, the fit of both models was still good with regard to all fit indices. There were no differences in correlations between the latent factors across school tracks. Note. WLE = Weighted Likelihood Estimate. The self-concept factors were estimated on a latent level, the achievement measures were included as manifest covariates in a CFA model. All correlations were highly significant (p b .001) unless marked by "n. s.". Note. CFI = comparative fit index; RMSEA = root mean square error of approximation; SRMR = standardized root mean square residual. a The difference from the three-factor model with freely estimated factor covariances. ⁎ p b .001.
body_text.section: The structure of the self-concept in science

body_text.text: In order to investigate differential relations between self-concept and academic achievement, we regressed each of the three subjectspecific self-concept factors on grades (see Fig. 2, Panel A) and test scores (see Fig. 2 , Panel B) in all three subjects. When using grades as a measure for achievement, the relation to the academic self-concept was substantial and highly subject-specific. The self-concept in each subject was best explained by grades in the same subject. In comparison, the cross-subject relations were relatively weak and did neither show contrast effects nor assimilation effects of relevant magnitude. When using test scores as a measure for achievement, the pattern of relations across the three subjects was less clear. In all three subjects, standardized test scores performed worse than grades in predicting the selfconcept and showed no subject-specificity in prediction. For instance, test scores in physics were positively related to the self-concept in all subjects.

Overall, there were substantial differential relations between academic achievement and the self-concept in the science subjects. Particularly when grades were used as a measure of achievement, the relations were subject-specific. With regard to cross-subject relations, the results showed no conclusive evidence for either contrast or assimilation effects.
Prior to examining potential gender differences, we tested the threefactor model of academic self-concept in science for measurement invariance across gender by means of MGCFA.

Based on the previously defined cut-off values for CFI differences when testing for invariance of the measurement component of the model (ΔCFI b .01 (Cheung & Rensvold, 2002) to ΔCFI b .002 (Meade et al., 2008) ), strict measurement invariance was established (see Table 5 ). Therefore, all further models were based on this assumption of strict measurement invariance. However, in the structural part of the model, constraining the covariances between the self-concept C SC 1 C SC 2 C SC 3 C SC 4 C SC 5 C SC 5 Fig. 1 . Three-factor model of academic self-concept in the science subjects including standardized parameters. a CFA model for all students. b Female students in an MGCFA assuming strict measure invariance. c Male students in an MGCFA assuming strict measure invariance. * p b .001.

Self-concept in chemistry Fig. 2 . MIMIC models of relations (standardized regression coefficients) between academic self-concept and achievement (Panel A: grades; Panel B: test scores) in the science subjects. R 2 refers to the variance explained for each self-concept factor. Error terms and residual correlations between the self-concept factors were estimated but omitted in this figure for clarity. * p b .001.

factors to be equal across gender groups led to a slight decline in model fit (S-B Δχ 2 (N = 6036, df = 3) = 18.69, p b .001, see Table 5 ). This was due to the correlation between the self-concept in biology and the self-concept in chemistry being lower for female students than for male students (see Fig. 1 ). When this correlation was free to vary across groups, constraining the other two correlations to be equal did not lead to a significant decrease in model fit (S-B Δχ 2 (N = 6036, df = 2) = 4.14, p = .874, see Table 5 ).

Mean differences in latent factor scores were analyzed for all three self-concept factors assuming strict measurement invariance. Latent means for male students were fixed to zero and freely estimated for the female group. The effect sizes can be found in Fig. 3 . The selfconcept in biology was marginally higher for female students (p = .033; d = 0.07), whereas the self-concepts in chemistry (p b .001; d = 0.35) and physics (p b .001; d = 0.70) were significantly higher for male students.

To meaningfully compare latent self-concept means while controlling for achievement, we first tested for moderating effects of gender on the regression coefficients between the self-concepts and achievement data. For grades, fixing the regression weights to be equal across gender groups did not lead to a significant decrease in model fit compared to a multigroup model in which regression weights were allowed to vary freely across gender groups, S-B Δχ 2 (N = 6035, df = 9) = 9.34, p = .406. This finding also held true for test scores, S-B Δχ 2 (N = 6035, df = 9) = 16.75, p = .052. Controlling for achievement data had only marginal effects on the mean differences in the latent self-concepts: For grades, the mean difference in biology was no longer significant (p = .496, d = 0.02), whereas the differences in chemistry (p b .001; d = 0.42) and physics (p b .001; d = 0.74) in favor of male students were of the same magnitude as in the model without covariates. For test scores, the marginal mean difference in biology (p = .038, d = 0.07) as well as the mean differences in chemistry (p b .001, d = 0.33) and physics (p b .001, d = 0.70) remained comparable. Overall, our results showed that invariant measurement models could be established across gender groups. We also found stereotypical mean differences in chemistry as well as physics.
We examined students' academic self-concept in three science subjects with regard to its dimensionality, its relations to academic achievement, and gender differences.

A three-factor model of academic self-concept showed superior model fit compared to a single-factor model. Students seem to perceive their ability in biology, chemistry, and physics as positively related but clearly distinguishable from each other. The moderate correlations between the self-concept factors were higher than typically found between the self-concepts in math and languages (Möller et al., 2009) , but considerably lower than the correlations between achievement measures in the three science subjects. Despite the potentially important differences in schooling (e.g., different amount of science lessons), this finding holds true for both students from different tracks (academic school track vs. non-academic school track). It should be noted that, considering the hierarchical structure of academic selfconcept assumed in the Shavelson model (Shavelson et al., 1976) , the relations can also be conceptualized in terms of a higher order factor model. In the specific case of three subjects, however, a higher order model and a model with correlated first-order factors are mathematically equivalent, at least, as long as no covariates are included in the model. Because the correlations between the three factors were only moderate, we decided to use the model with three correlated self-concept factors.
body_text.section: Dimensionality of academic self-concept in the science subjects

body_text.text: In educational research, the self-concept in science is often conceptualized as a one-dimensional construct (e.g., Nagengast et al., 2011) . In the light of our results, we recommend examining the self-concept in specific science subjects. The nature of these subjects may vary depending on the country or state in which a study is conducted. Whereas biology, chemistry and physics are the most common science subjects in Germany and it therefore seems appropriate to assess self-concept in these subjects, a different learning environment may require researchers to assess the self-concept in other subdomains of science. . Positive values indicate a higher academic self-concept for female students while negative values indicate a higher academic self-concept for male students. Errors bar represent 95% confidence intervals.
body_text.section: Dimensionality of academic self-concept in the science subjects

body_text.text: Our results extend previous research that showed that subjectspecific measures of the self-concept are better predictors of academic achievement, motivation, or course choice than general measures of self-concept and stress the importance of conceptualizing the selfconcept as a multidimensional construct Marsh & Martin, 2011; Marsh & O' Mara, 2008) . That is, the selfconcepts in biology, chemistry and physics should not only be distinguished in theoretical models of academic self-concept but also behave differently empirically as shown in their subject-specific relations to achievement measures and gender differences that are present only in chemistry and physics but not in biology.
body_text.section: Dimensionality of academic self-concept in the science subjects

body_text.text: When using grades as an achievement measure, we found substantial, subject-specific relations between self-concept and achievement. Grades were a valid predictor of self-concept in the same subject, whereas grades in the other two science subjects did not prove to be incrementally useful in explaining the self-concept. This subjectspecificity of relations between self-concept and achievement is in line with a recent meta-analysis (Huang, 2011) that showed that subjectspecific operationalization moderates the effect of academic selfconcept on academic achievement. When using test scores from a standardized achievement measure, the predictive power was considerably reduced and not subject-specific. Overall, students' selfconcept in science seems to be based on their recent grades rather than on their actual science proficiency as measured by standardized achievement tests. There are several possible reasons for the different predictive validity of achievement measures for the selfconcept in science. First, there is a high conceptual overlap between these two constructs: grades are likely the most salient source of individual feedback for students, and they play an important role in forming and shaping a specific self-concept (Marsh et al., 2005) . Second, in addition to academic achievement in science, grades also reflect social, conative, and emotional factors, among them motivation and interest. Put differently, a teacher's grading may take into account a student's effort (e.g., completion of coursework and homework) and compliant classroom behavior. These factors have been shown to be positively related to the academic self-concept as well (Trautwein et al., 2006) which may explain the more pronounced relation between the academic selfconcept and grades. Third, the individual self-concept is evaluated in comparison to a reference group, normally the school class. Similarly, grades, to an extent, are given in the reference frame of a school class ("grading on curve").

With regard to relations between the self-concept and achievement measures across subjects, no evidence for either contrast or assimilation effects was found. This does not necessarily mean that students do not engage in dimensional comparisons between their abilities in different science subjects. It is conceivable, that positive assimilation effects and negative contrast effects between two subjects are present at the same time leveling each other out. An analysis of path coefficients as conducted in our study is not suitable to disentangle such opposing effects, but only indicate whether there is a positive or negative net effect of the dimensional comparisons (Möller & Marsh, 2013; . It may also be that the core subjects (the language of instruction and math) are more salient anchors of comparison for students than science subjects, especially regarding the importance of the distinction between mathematics and the verbal domain. Therefore, the effects of achievement on self-concept between specific science subjects could be negligible.

Measurement invariance across gender groups was established for the three-dimensional self-concept model. No gender-specific effects on the relation between the self-concept and academic achievement were found. Mean differences in the latent self-concept scores were stereotypical in nature such that male students showed higher selfconcepts in chemistry and physics even after controlling for achievement. Effect sizes were small to moderate for chemistry and moderate to high for physics. The self-concept of female students in physics and to a lesser degree in chemistry did not correspond to their ability as measured by grades and test scores, that is, female students tended to underestimate their ability compared to male students. As the selfconcept is not only reciprocally related to achievement but is also a valid predictor of the choice of academic courses (Marsh & Yeung, 1997) and career aspirations in science (Nagengast et al., 2011) , diverging self-concepts may be an important factor in explaining the gender gap found in universities. Interventions developed to enhance the selfconcept are effective when they, first, target a domain-specific selfconcept rather than general self-related constructs such as self-esteem and, second, focus on students with a low prior self-concept (O' Mara, Marsh, Craven, & Debus, 2006) . Enhancing female students' general academic self-concept or even the general self-concept in science will not necessarily lead to a higher self-concept in STEM areas where the gender gap is particularly large-that is, chemistry and physics and also computer science or engineering. Therefore, a practical application of our findings would be to apply subject-specific interventions in order to foster female students' self-concepts in STEM subjects.
body_text.section: Stereotypical gender differences and bridging the gender gap in STEM

body_text.text: In the present study, we only measured self-concept in three subjects from the domain of science. By additionally measuring the selfconcept in other school subjects, for instance, in mathematics and languages, future research may shed light on how self-concepts in science should be integrated into models representing the internal structure of the academic self-concept-most notably the Marsh/Shavelson model and the I/E model. For example, it could be explored whether contrast or assimilation effects of dimensional comparisons occur between languages, math and the sciences allowing for a more precise positioning of the science on the verbal-mathematical continuum. Ideally, such a study should also explore students' subjective beliefs about the nature of the three science subjects in order to describe the underlying processes of dimensional comparison. Do the students, for example, believe that chemistry and physics are "harder" science subjects than biology because they require more mathematical skills? And do these perceived subject characteristics predict the strength of relations between the selfconcept factors? Further, our study did not include measures of general academic self-concept or general science self-concept. Including such measures in future studies would allow for the test and meaningful interpretation of nested factor models which have recently been employed to model the structure of academic self-concept (Brunner et al., 2010) .
body_text.section: Limitations and directions for future research

body_text.text: Because the three sciences biology, chemistry and physics are mandatory part of secondary school curricula in nearly all German schools, we think our results can be generalized to other German tenthgraders even though the sample was not completely representative (e.g., only eight of 16 federal states were included). Our results may not be generalized to younger students, however, because selfconcept becomes more differentiated with age (Marsh, 1989; Shavelson et al., 1976; Stipek & Mac Iver, 1989) and the relations between subject-specific self-concepts in the sciences may therefore be higher for younger students. Also, in some German federal states and mostly in the non-academic school track, science is taught interdisciplinarily in lower grades which may be an additional reason to expect a less differentiated self-concept for younger students with special regard to science subjects.
body_text.section: Limitations and directions for future research

body_text.text: Further, our results may not be generalized to student populations outside of Germany. While cross-national studies on the relations between academic self-concept and achievement found no different effect pattern across cultures (Marsh & Hau, 2004; Nagengast & Marsh, 2012; Seaton, Marsh, & Craven, 2009) , it is plausible to expect differences in the structure of academic self-concept due to differences in science education (e.g., the number and nature of science subjects that are taught) given that self-concept develops within the context of the learning environments that students are exposed to. Further cross-cultural research is needed to examine whether the structure of students' self-concept is based on school subjects and, thus, specific to schooling systems, or on content areas and, thus, global. For example, it would be interesting to compare students that are taught science as an interdisciplinary subject with students that are taught in separate science subjects with regard to their self-concept structure.
body_text.section: Limitations and directions for future research

body_text.text: The data at hand were cross-sectional. Therefore, our results could not shed light on the causal relation between achievement and the self-concept in science or their development over time. Although it is likely that the self-concept and achievement are mutually dependentas has been shown numerous times in other subjects such as math Marsh & Martin, 2011 )gathering longitudinal data on the relation between the self-concept and achievement in science would be desirable. Ideally, a longitudinal study should include course choices in school and career choices to better understand the aggravation of the gender gap over time for STEM subjects.
body_text.section: Limitations and directions for future research
